sections.title: Take your next step
content_html: Get everything you need with a full Florida Notary Supply Package.

sections.title: About the Florida Notary Process
content_html: Florida Notaries have a four-year commission term. To continue notarizing documents, renewing Notaries are required to follow the steps with the exception of the training course.

sections.title: Cost of Becoming an FL Notary
content_html: The cost to become a Florida Notary ranges between $99 - $164. This is dependent on where you complete your Notary training course and purchase your seal.
Get your state-required training and supplies for a Florida Notary commission with the NNA.

sections.title: Commission Processing Time
content_html: It can take two to four weeks to become commissioned as a Notary Public depending on your availability and the time the Department of State needs to process your application.
To ensure there’s no delay with the review of your application, use our free application wizard to avoid errors.

sections.title: Florida Notary Public Requirements
content_html: Wondering if you qualify to become a Notary in the Sunshine State? Check out the requirements below.

sections.title: Eligibility
content_html: You may become a Notary in Florida if you meet the following requirements:

• Be at least 18 years old
  • Be a legal resident of Florida
  • Not be a convicted felon unless you have had your civil rights restored

sections.title: Notary Training
content_html: All first-time applicants for a Florida Notary Public commission must complete a three-hour course offered by the state or by an education provider approved by the Executive Office of the Governor.
At the end of the course, you will receive a completion certificate that must be submitted with your application form.
Please note: You must complete the Notary class within one year prior to applying for a Notary commission.

sections.title: Application
content_html: Complete and submit the application along with your training completion certificate and fee.
Below are a few tips when filling out the application:

• Affidavit of Character: A person who has known you for more than a year must complete this section.
  • Oath of Office: Make sure you are able and willing to swear or affirm the oath of office.
Submit your application error-free with the NNA’s application wizard.

sections.title: Notary Supplies
content_html: Florida Notaries are required to use an inked rubber stamp seal as the official Notary seal for all notarial acts. The seal must include the following information:

• Your name as it appears on your commission
  • The words "Notary Public - State of Florida"
  • Your commission number
  • Your commission expiration date

sections.title: Surety Bond
content_html: Florida law requires you to get a $7,500 bond from a surety company authorized to do business in Florida.
Once your application is approved by the Department of State, you will receive your commission certificate from your bonding agency.

sections.title: Florida Notary Public FAQs
content_html: Find more information about being a Notary Public in Florida below.
